      <script type="text/javascript">
        window.__PRELOADED_STATE__ = {"abstracts":{"content":[{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"sectitle0010"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"__text__","_":"Graphite, the most prominent anode material for Li-ion battery, exhibited very poor performance in sodium ion battery. The electrochemical intercalation of Na"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"+"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" ions in graphite is impeded due to smaller interlayer spacing. Here, we have reported ASR derived hard carbon as a suitable anode electroactive material for Na-ion battery. Prepared via single step selective thermal transformation, the hard carbons contain defects, heteroatoms, nanopore, and ordered carbon zones with expanded interlayer spacing. Among all the hard carbons, the hard carbon synthesised at 1100 "},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"mo","_":"°C"}],"#name":"mrow"}],"$":{"xmlns:mml":true,"altimg":"si1.svg"},"#name":"math"},{"#name":"__text__","_":", showed better electrochemical performance owing to its improved structural and morphological properties. The electrochemical study reveals that hard carbon synthesised at 1100 "},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"mo","_":"°C"}],"#name":"mrow"}],"$":{"xmlns:mml":true,"altimg":"si1.svg"},"#name":"math"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" provides initial reversible capacity of 434mAh/g at a current density of 10 mA/g with a capacity retention of 53% after 100 cycles. Issues like global warming and climate changes have made human to shift their energy choices from fossil fuels to renewable sources. Although Li-ion battery is currently dominating the energy market, yet it falls short to meet the growing large scale energy storage system (EES) demand. Na-ion battery is considered as a worthy contender for growing ESS. The hard carbon studied in this work, can be a potential candidate for use as anode active material in Na-ion battery."}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"abspara0010"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"abssec0010"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"abs0010","lang":"en","class":"author"},"#name":"abstract"},{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"sectitle0015"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Graphical publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button><div class="banner-options u-padding-xs-bottom"><div class="toc-button-wrap u-display-inline-block u-display-none-from-lg u-margin-s-right"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 128 128" height="20" class="icon icon-list"><path d="M23 26a9 9 0 0 0-9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9-9 9 9 0 0 0-9-9zm23 4v10h68V30zM23 56a9 9 0 0 0-9 class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2023.233577" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2023.233577</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0378775323009539&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom"><div class="License"><span>Under a Creative Commons </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/" target="_blank" class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Open access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0020" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0020"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0020"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Structural and morphological properties of hard carbon synthesised from ASR.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Electrochemical properties of hard carbon as anode materials of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about sodium ion battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion battery</a>.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Sodium ion interaction with hard carbon during electrochemical operation.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">In situ doping mechanism of heteroatoms present in hard carbon.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010"><span><span>Graphite, the most prominent <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for Li-ion battery, exhibited very poor performance in </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion battery</a>. The electrochemical intercalation of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> ions in graphite is impeded due to smaller interlayer spacing. Here, we have reported ASR derived hard carbon as a suitable anode electroactive material for Na-ion battery. Prepared via single step selective thermal transformation, the hard carbons contain defects, heteroatoms, <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopore from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopore</a>, and ordered carbon zones with expanded interlayer spacing. Among all the hard carbons, the hard carbon synthesised at 1100 </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span>, showed better <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> owing to its improved structural and morphological properties. The electrochemical study reveals that hard carbon synthesised at 1100 </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span> provides initial reversible capacity of 434mAh/g at a current density of 10&nbsp;mA/g with a capacity retention of 53% after 100 cycles. Issues like global warming and climate changes have made human to shift their energy choices from <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/fossil-fuel" title="Learn more about fossil fuels from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fossil fuels</a> to renewable sources. Although Li-ion battery is currently dominating the energy market, yet it falls short to meet the growing large scale energy storage system (EES) demand. Na-ion battery is considered as a worthy contender for growing ESS. The hard carbon studied in this work, can be a potential candidate for use as anode active material in Na-ion battery.</span></div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="undfig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt="Image 1"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (279KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (279KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775323009242"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775323009801"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>Hard carbon</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Automotive shredder residue (ASR)</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Anode</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Sodium ion battery</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>Rechargeable Na-ion batteries (NIBs) are considered one of the propitious energy storage systems which can help and give a solution to eradicate the environmental alterations caused by excessive <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/fossil-fuel" title="Learn more about fossil fuels from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fossil fuels</a><span><span> consumption. It is the time demand that we should divert our choice of energy consumption from <a href="/topics/materials-science/fossil-fuel" title="Learn more about fossil fuels from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fossil fuels</a> to </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/renewable-energy" title="Learn more about renewable energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">renewable energy</a>, produced from sources like wind, tidal wave, solar etc. Most of the renewable energy producing systems use interim energy storage systems to store the energy and then integrate with the main electrical power system [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a><span>]. NIB could be a better candidate for using as interim energy storage device in the large-scale energy storage system due to their excellent features like cost-effectiveness, safety, <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a>, and portability [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a><span><span>]. To the greatest extent, now a days the major portion of NIBs research is focused on positive electrode materials of NIBs. In this article, importance has been given to a new possible <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for NIBs which has been fabricated using the hard carbons synthesised from automotive shredder residue (ASR). The primary perspective of this study is to introduce the ASR as a potential source of carbon materials for energy storage systems and elucidate the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of the hard carbons synthesised from ASR as an anode material in Na-ion battery.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">From the beginning of Li-ion battery (LIB) commercialisation, graphite has been used as anode material in LIBs. The performance of graphite as anode material in LIBs is quite satisfactory. But graphite garnered a poor reputation when used as anode material in NIB. The interlayer spacing of graphite (0.335&nbsp;nm) is not suitable for Na<sup>+</sup> ion insertion during the electrochemical sodiation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>]. The reversible capacity of graphite as anode material in NIB is <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-69-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;lt;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.625ex" viewBox="0 -598.2 778.5 699.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">&lt;</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-69"><math><mrow is="true"><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">&lt;</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 35mAhg<sup>−1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a><span>]. Limitation of graphite as anode material in NIB has paved the way for other <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carbonaceous-material" title="Learn more about carbonaceous materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonaceous materials</a> to be used as anode material in NIBs. For instance, various kind of non-graphitic carbonaceous materials like hard carbons [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a><span>], soft carbons, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbons</a> have been tested as anode material in NIBs [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>]. Among all these carbonaceous materials, hard carbons have grasped the special attention due to their high thermal stability, low cost, and availability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>]. Hard carbons are consisted of randomly oriented microdomains and loosely stacked layer of graphene with larger interlayer spacing than the graphite [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. In hard carbons, the Na<sup>+</sup> ion can easily store in expanded graphite layer, defects at the graphene plane, and nanovoids in between randomly stacked graphite layer. The large interlayer spacing of hard carbons acts as buffer during Na<sup>+</sup> ion insertion, because it helps to avoid the volume changes caused by Na<sup>+</sup> ion insertion. On the contrary soft carbons have smaller amount of nanovoids and lesser interlayer spacing in comparison with hard carbons. Though the soft carbons contain some amount of turbostratic carbon, the Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage in soft carbon is lower than the hard carbon. The situation is much worse for graphite. The orderly stacked graphene layer and the absence of nanovoids allow graphite to store very few amount of Na<sup>+</sup> ions at the graphene edges [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>]. The unique microstructure of hard carbons facilitates the sodiation/desodiation process in NIB during electrochemical operation. Recent studies on hard carbons say that most of the hard carbons provide specific capacities between 200mAh/g to 300mAh/g as anode material in NIB [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0045">In this work an attempt has been made to synthesis hard carbons from ASR and use them as anode active material in NIB. Around 50 million ton of end-of-life vehicles (ELVs) are generated per year which is responsible for producing approximately 50 million ton of waste per year [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a><span>]. Usually, ELVs contain 70–75% <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ferrous-metal" title="Learn more about ferrous metal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ferrous metal</a>, 5% non-ferrous metal, and 20–25% automotive shredder residue (ASR) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>]. It is projected that by the end of 2030 the amount ASR will reach 9 million ton [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>]. Abandoning landfilled ASR is a serious threat to the environment due to the presence of various organic compounds in ASR. ASR usually contains plastic (35–55%), rubber (10–20%), wood (15–40%), and textile and other materials (5–15%). Recovery of potential value-added materials like plastic, rubber, and biomass have been turned into the topic of research now a days [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a><span><span>]. The recovered value materials are used for manufacturing of composite filler, thermosetting filler, fuel synthesis, etc. Synthesis of carbonaceous materials from ASR is a unique, sustainable, and innovative timely concept to use as anode material <a href="/topics/materials-science/feedstock" title="Learn more about feedstock from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">feedstock</a> for </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion battery</a>. In this study, three carbon materials were synthesised from ASR at 700&nbsp;°C, 900&nbsp;°C, and 1100&nbsp;°C. The hard carbon derived from ASR at 1100&nbsp;°C (ASR-11) showed better electrochemical performance compared to other anodes. This hard carbon exhibited high initial reversible capacity of 434mAh/g at 10&nbsp;mA/g and hold a capacity retention of 53% after 100 cycles. The material's performance parameters reported here as anode active material in NIB are on par with the currently used carbon materials synthesised from different sources. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl1" name="btbl1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a> summarised the performances of some carbon materials from existing literature and the performance of ASR derived hard carbon as anode material in Na-ion battery.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl1"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="tspara0010"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. Performances of carbon materials synthesised from different sources vs the performances of carbon material studied in this work as anode active material in NIB.</p></span></span><div class="align-left"><strong>434</strong></td><td class="align-left" rowspan="3"><strong>No additional material treatment.</strong></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left"><strong>100</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>100</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>70</strong></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">The automotive shredder residue (ASR) used in this experimental study was supplied by OneSteel Australia. The as received ASRs were profuse in wood and plastic. The composition of the as received ASR is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">At the very onset of this study, the ground ASR was thermally transformed into hard carbon via a single step process. For thermal transformation, ASR was heat treated at 700 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-74-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-74"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, 900 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-75-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-75"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, and 1100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-76-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-76"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span> for 1&nbsp;h in a High Temperature Tube Furnace in an inert atmosphere created by nitrogen <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/gas-flow" title="Learn more about gas flow from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">gas flow</a> at the rate of 1L/min. The experimental conditions and furnace schematic are demonstrated in supporting information (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>). The hard carbon synthesised at 700 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-77-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-77"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, 900 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-78-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-78"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, and 1100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-79-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-79"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> are identified as ASR-7, ASR-9, and ASR-11 respectively. These hard carbons were used and assessed as anode active material in Na-ion battery. The anodes made from ASR-7, ASR-9, ASR-11 are named ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A respectively.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Materials characterisation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span><span>To study the compositions, morphology and microstructure of the hard carbons, the ASR-7, ASR-9, and ASR-11 were characterised in depth by <a href="/topics/materials-science/elemental-analysis" title="Learn more about CHNS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CHNS analysis</a>, X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF), X-ray </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/photoelectron" title="Learn more about photoelectron from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photoelectron</a> spectroscopy (XPS), thermal gravimetric/thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, X-ray diffraction (XRD), </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a><span> (TEM) and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/laser-ablation" title="Learn more about laser ablation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">laser ablation</a> </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/inductively-coupled-plasma-mass-spectrometry" title="Learn more about inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry</a><span> (LA-ICP-MS) analytical technique was used to measure the elemental composition of ASR. The percentage of remaining carbon in ASR composition was estimated by LECO CS230 carbon and sulfur analyser. Furthermore, the carbon, hydrogen, sulfur, and oxygen percentage in ASR were estimated by utilising CHNSO combustion analyser. An Elementar vario MACRO CUBE and a rapid OXY CUBE were used for CHNS and O analysis respectively. To understand the <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermal-degradation" title="Learn more about thermal degradation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal degradation</a> behavior of ASR, TGA was performed by using a PerkinElmer TGA 800 thermal gravimetric analyser. BET test was accomplished on a Micromeritics TriStar 3020 II surface analysis system. For X-ray diffraction analysis, the samples were scanned from 10 </span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-80-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.162ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 500.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 1.257ex; margin-bottom: -1.377ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-80"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></script></span> to 50 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-81-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.162ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 500.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 1.257ex; margin-bottom: -1.377ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-81"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></script></span> in a PANalytical X'Pert Multipurpose XRD System (MPD) equipped with Cu K <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-82-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B1;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.488ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 640.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B1"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-82"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></script></span> radiation (λ&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.541&nbsp;Å). The TEM images were captured in JEOL TEM-F200, operated in TEM mode at spot size 1, angle 5, emission current 14 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-83-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BC;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.402ex" height="1.855ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 603.5 798.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BC"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">μ</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-83"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">μ</mi></mrow></math></script></span> m, and 200&nbsp;kV accelerating voltage. An ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Scientific, UK) X-ray photoelectron spectrometer was utilised for measuring the chemical states of elements present at the surface of the materials. The XPS analyser was equipped with a mono-chromated Al K<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-84-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B1;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.488ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 640.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B1"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-84"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></script></span><span> (hʋ&nbsp;=&nbsp;1486.68&nbsp;eV) X-ray source. The XPS analysis was performed in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultrahigh-vacuum" title="Learn more about ultrahigh vacuum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ultrahigh vacuum</a> (∼2&nbsp;×&nbsp;10</span><sup>−9</sup>&nbsp;mbar) with a photoelectron take off angle of 90 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-85-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.162ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 500.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 1.257ex; margin-bottom: -1.377ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-85"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span>. C1s (at 284.5&nbsp;eV) of graphite was used as the binding energy reference. For Raman characterisation, a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope was used equipped with an <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/argon-laser" title="Learn more about argon ion laser from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">argon ion laser</a> of 532&nbsp;nm.</span></div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. The electrochemical measurements of half-cell</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>At the very outset of electrochemical measurement, the hard carbon-based electrodes were fabricated to study the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performances from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performances</a><span> of hard carbons as electrode materials of NIB. For preparing the electrodes, the hard carbons, carbon black (AVT services), and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a> fluoride (PVDF; AVT services) binder were mixed at the weight ratio of 85:10:5 to make a powder mixture. Then the N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP; sigma Aldrich) was added dropwise to the mixture followed by magnetic stirring of the mixture for 24&nbsp;h to form a viscous slurry. The slurry was coated (coating thickness was 80 </span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-86-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BC;</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>m</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.442ex" height="1.855ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 1482 798.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BC"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(603,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6D"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">μ</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-86"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">μ</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></mrow></math></script></span>) in a copper foil by a notch bar and dried in a vacuum oven at 100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-87-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-87"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> for 12&nbsp;h. After the vacuum drying, to improve the adhesion between the pasted electrode and copper foil, the electrode sheets were pressed at 100&nbsp;kN pressure for 1&nbsp;h by using a flat-plate presser (MTI corporation). These sheets were then dried in a vacuum oven at 100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-88-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-88"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span> for 6&nbsp;h then transferred in glovebox filled with argon. Inside the glovebox the electrode sheets were pressed to form 12&nbsp;mm discs with the help of a handheld punching machine. CR2032 type NIB half cells were prepared by using hard carbon-based electrodes as anode, pure <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> metal as counter electrode, and 16&nbsp;mm glass fibre (Whatman, grade GF/F) as separator. 1&nbsp;M NaPF</span><sub>6</sub> in ethylene carbonate (EC)/dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (1:1 by volume) was employed as electrolyte. 41,42 NaPF<sub>6</sub>, DMC, and EC were delivered from Sigma-Aldrich. A Neware BTS3000 battery cycler was employed for cycling the cells galvanostatically between 0.01v-2.5v at varying current densities. The applied current values were measured depending on the mass loading (4.5&nbsp;mg/cm<sup>2</sup>) of electroactive materials at the electrodes (foil with 12&nbsp;mm diameter contained 5.0&nbsp;mg active material).</div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Result and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">The percentage of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, sulfur, and oxygen in ASR and thermally treated ASR residue (hard carbons) was measured by CHNSO analyser. The LECO CS230 analyser was used for measuring the amount of residual carbon in the samples. The elemental composition of ASR samples measured by LA-ICP-MS and LECO CS230 analyser is summarised in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl2" name="btbl2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl2"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="tspara0015"><span class="label">Table 2</span>. Trace elements and carbon content in ASR samples.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">Sample</th><th scope="col">C (%)</th><th class="align-left">2.32</td><td class="align-left">2.43</td><td class="align-left">0.23</td><td class="align-left">0.003</td><td class="align-left">0.01</td><td class="align-left">0.23</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-7</td><td class="align-left">80.12</td><td class="align-left">0.95</td><td class="align-left">0.73</td><td class="align-left">1.91</td><td class="align-left">0.28</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0.02</td><td class="align-left">0.04</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.08</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0.15</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-9</td><td class="align-left">81.11</td><td class="align-left">0.94</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.04</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.08</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">Carbon percentage in ASR samples measured by both LECO CS230 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl2" name="btbl2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>) and CHNSO analyser (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>) are quite similar. Nitrogen content (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a><span>) increased significantly with increasing the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonisation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonisation</a><span> temperature. This phenomenon can be associated with thermal transformation of nitrogen into stable phases at higher temperature. The elemental data analysis summarises that the hard carbons consist of 80–81% carbon and 10–20% different kinds of heteroatoms. This huge number of heteroatoms influences the performances of hard carbons during electrochemical operation. The impact of the presence of heteroatoms on potentiogram of hard carbons has been illustrated in subsequent sections. To understand the thermal stability of ASR, the ASR was subjected to <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about thermal gravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal gravimetric analysis</a>. The ASR begun to degrade around 350 </span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-89-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-89"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3a</span></span></a>) and continued till the temperature reached around 525 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-90-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-90"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span>. Throughout this <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermal-degradation" title="Learn more about thermal degradation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal degradation</a> process, ASR loses around 30% of its mass. The Thermal degradation of ASR shows a step around 450 </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-91-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-91"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a>). Beyond <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-92-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-92"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 525<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-93-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; Percentage of N, O, C, H, and S in ASR samples measured by CHNSO combustion analyser.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">Sample</th><th scope="col">N (%)</th><th scope="col">O (%)</th><th scope="col">C (%)</th><th scope="col">H (%)</th><th scope="col">S (%)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR</td><td class="align-left">0.21</td><td class="align-left">6.32</td><td class="align-left">20.32</td><td class="align-left">1.05</td><td class="align-left">0.35</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-7</td><td class="align-left">1.61</td><td class="align-left">7.31</td><td class="align-left">80.23</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.01</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-9</td><td class="align-left">1.74</td><td class="align-left">8.11</td><td class="align-left">81.31</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-11</td><td class="align-left">1.73</td><td class="align-left">8.36</td><td class="align-left">81.29</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><span>The elemental composition of the hard carbons, and anodes (after charging and discharging) was estimated by <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS analysis</a>. The elements identified at the surface of the hard carbons are mainly C, O, and Na. Pristine ASR sample is the source for most of these elements. The presence of Na in the XPS spectra is not surprising. The presence of Na can be related to Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> ion intercalation in hard carbons during electrochemical operation. One of the prime objectives behind the XPS study was to reveal the changes that took place regarding the composition, bond association and chemical states of elements at the surface of <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> due to charging and discharging. The deconvoluted C1s peaks at 284.8&nbsp;eV, </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-96-Frame" tabindex="0" is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(795,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g><g is="true"
