text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. Visual representation of Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ions storage in hard carbons: (a) Na<sup>+</sup> ions storage at different defect sites; (b) Na<sup>+</sup> ions storage in nano pore and between two expanded graphene layers; (c) Deformation of graphene layer due to the presence of different size heteroatoms; (d) Enlarging in interlayer spacing due to the presence of heteroatoms and functional groups.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">The elemental characterisation (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl2" name="btbl2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>) reveals that the hard carbon contains a significant number of heteroatoms (i.e., Si, N, Al, Ca, Mg, Fe, etc.). Heteroatoms like Si and N, from group number 14 and 15 can react with the Na<sup>+</sup><span> ions and form <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/intermetallics" title="Learn more about intermetallic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">intermetallic</a> compounds which are considered as alloying or dealloying of these elements with Na. These alloying or dealloying of heteroatoms with Na</span><sup>+</sup> ions increase the specific capacity because one single atom can anchor multiple Na atoms. The alloying or dealloying reaction of these elements with Na<sup>+</sup> ions has been stated below.<span class="display"><span id="fd2" class="formula"><span class="label">2</span><span is="true">(</mo><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">i</mi><mo is="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" mathvariant="normal" is="true">c</mi><mo is="true">.</mo><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">y</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" stretchy="true" is="true">→</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">y</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The equation of multi electron reaction during electrochemical operation can be expressed as below.<span class="display"><span id="fd3" class="formula"><span class="label">3</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-132-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>y</mi></msub><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>X</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>z</mi></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>n</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>z</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>n</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>z</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2212;</mo></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2192;</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>y</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>z</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>X</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="44.26ex" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7A"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1390,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5725,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(750,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1251,410)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7849,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8850,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(946,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7A"></use></g><g transform="translate(444,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(12169,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2192"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(13447,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-79"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(13976,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(15115,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(16116,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7A"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(444,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1195,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1695,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6E"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(18305,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-58"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">y</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" stretchy="true" is="true">→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">y</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">X</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-132"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">y</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" stretchy="true" is="true">→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">y</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">X</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">Here, X in compounds M<sub>y</sub>X<sub>z</sub>, and Na<sub>n</sub><span><span>M represents <a href="/topics/materials-science/halide" title="Learn more about halide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">halide</a>, phosphide, or </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-hydride" title="Learn more about metal hydride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal hydride</a>. With increasing the atomic number of electropositive elements, the M-X bond becomes more ionic and strong, thus irreversible capacity loss increases causing low ICE [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib69" name="bbib69" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib69"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a><span><span>]. One point must be mentioned here that the presence of large heteroatoms (e.g., Al, Si, Ti, Ca, Mg, etc.) in hard carbons may cause stress and form cracks. The continuous exposure of the cracked surface to the electrolyte during electrochemical operation results in the formation of new <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about SEI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEI</a> layers. As a result, the cyclic stability and reversibility of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reactions</a> may decrease [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib69" name="bbib69" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib69"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">69</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">However, the presence of heteroatoms leads to achieve favorable binding energy (negative binding energy) for sodium ion storage into graphene sheets [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib70" name="bbib70" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib70"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">70</span></span></a><span>]. Heteroatoms like Al (electron acceptor), Si (isovalent), and N (electron donor) act as in situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/doping-additives" title="Learn more about dopants from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dopants</a> and influence the property of hard carbons. In Si–C and Al–C system, C being more electronegative than the Si and Al, C drags the outer shell electrons of Si and Al towards it. As a result, negative charge localises around the neighboring C atoms of Si and Al in the graphene sheets [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib71" name="bbib71" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib71"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">71</span></span></a><span>]. In consequence strong interaction between sodium atom and graphene sheet grows up around the heteroatoms. Along with the negative charge localisation, Al also creates holes (act as p-type dopants) in the host lattice which improves the electrical conductivity of the hard carbons by increasing <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carrier-mobility" title="Learn more about carrier mobility from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carrier mobility</a>. However, for N the situation is different than p-type dopants and isovalents (Si). Nitrogen, being more electronegative than the carbon, it draws the electrons from carbon's outer shell towards itself and induces polarisation in adjacent carbon network [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib71" name="bbib71" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib71"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">71</span></span></a>]. Thus, nitrogen localises negative charge around itself making the neighboring carbon atoms to become positively charged. However, the doping behavior of N depends on its bond configuration with carbon atoms. Nitrogen usually shows three bond configurations [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib72" name="bbib72" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">72</span></span></a>]: (i) graphitic/quaternary (n-type), (ii) pyridinic (p-type), and (iii) pyrrolic (p-type). Due to in plane bond formation with carbon atoms, graphitic nitrogen contributes electron to the <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-133-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C0;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.332ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 573.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-133"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi></mrow></math></script></span> network of surrounding carbon atoms and act as an n-type dopant. On the contrary, pyrrolic and pyridinic nitrogen being bonded with carbons at defect sites behave as p-type dopant due to their electron withdrawing tendency from the carbon network. However, all these types of nitrogen increase the carrier concentration. Oxygen is a very strong electronegative element; thus, it is quite impossible for oxygen to form substitutional doping in graphene sheet. But, the presence of oxygen containing functional groups (C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O, C–O–C, C–OH, COOH/COOR, etc.) in carbon is considered as oxygen doping [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib72" name="bbib72" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib72"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">72</span></span></a>]. The covalent bonding of oxygen containing functional groups converts sp<sup>2</sup> carbon into sp<sup>3</sup> carbon, leading to distortion in graphene sheet. In consequence of structural alteration, the conductivity of carbons reduces due to an increase in the amount of sp<sup>3</sup> hybridisation carbons. Along with the above nonmetallic elements, the hard carbon contains some metallic elements like Al, Ca, Mg, Fe, etc. All these metallic elements are electropositive than carbon and have electron deficiency at their valance shell. Owing to electron deficiency, these metallic elements act as electron acceptors and create holes in the lattice, thus inducing p-type doping effects in the hard carbon lattice. However, due to bigger atomic size, the presence of these metallic elements creates distortion and defects in the lattice (visual representation of lattice deformation is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c). Along with heteroatoms, vacancy also plays an important role in Na<sup>+</sup> ions storage. The defective sp-bonded carbons in vacancy, develop negative charges around themselves, create favorable locations for binding sodium atoms. Strong binding energy between Na<sup>+</sup><span> ions and <a href="/topics/materials-science/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> favor the Na</span><sup>+</sup> ions intercalation, as a result, Na<sup>+</sup><span> ions easily get anchored at vacancy defect sites. When sodium intercalates at the defect sites, the carbon pulls the valence electron density of sodium towards the carbon ring. In consequence, electron density difference rises between sodium and carbon ring making the <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-bonding" title="Learn more about bond ionic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">bond ionic</a> in nature [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib70" name="bbib70" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib70"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">70</span></span></a><span>]. Moreover, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> enhance the Na</span><sup>+</sup> ions insertion into hard carbons during electrochemical operation and this phenomenon can be associated with the capacity at sloping region.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160"><span>Functional groups play heavyweight performances like anchoring the heteroatoms at the surface of hard carbons via <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrostatics" title="Learn more about electrostatic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic</a> interaction/Van der Waals force/ </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-134-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C0;</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2212;</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C0;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.504ex" height="1.855ex" viewBox="0 -647.8 2369.9 798.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.351ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(795,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1796,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">−</mo><mi is="true">π</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-134"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">−</mo><mi is="true">π</mi></mrow></math></script></span> stacking/covalent bond formation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib73" name="bbib73" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib73"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">73</span></span></a><span>]. Alongside heteroatoms, the sodium atoms might have been anchored by the oxygen containing functional groups at the <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about carbon surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon surface</a> and lead to achieve high specific capacity. These oxygen containing functional groups anchored the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> ions via surface <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> during electrochemical operation [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib74" name="bbib74" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib74"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">74</span></span></a>]: -C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O&nbsp;+&nbsp;Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;=&nbsp;-C-O-Na. Therefore, this surface redox reaction contributes to electrochemical energy storage of NIB. Besides, presence of oxygen containing functional groups leads to expansion in graphene layers with increased interlayer spacing [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib75" name="bbib75" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib75"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">75</span></span></a>]. The attachment of the functional groups at both the sides of graphene layer gives rise to distortion in interlayer structure and localised small range ordered carbon domain with expanded interlayer spacing by breaking down the long-range graphitic order. Here one point must be mentioned that it’s not only the functional groups, which are responsible for enlarging the interlayer spacing, in addition, the intercalation of heteroatoms at the middle of graphite sheet are also responsible for increasing the interlayer spacing (the schematic related to interlayer expansion and distortion of graphene plane due to the presence of heteroatoms and functional groups have been displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d). It is reported that the electrochemical insertion of Na<sup>+</sup> ions in ordered graphite is thermodynamically impractical but Na<sup>+</sup> ions insertion in large interlayer spacing is thermodynamically viable [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib65" name="bbib65" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib65"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">65</span></span></a>]. Large interlayer spacing makes it easy for the Na<sup>+</sup> ions to move freely between two graphene layers and offers more space for Na<sup>+</sup><span> ions storage which ultimately contributes to the plateau capacity of the potentiogram. Finally, yet importantly, <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopores</a> are one of the most important structural features of hard carbons. From the BET result it is demonstrated that the hard carbons synthesised in this study contain nanopores. Owing to low binding energy, nanopores have been acted as preferable Na</span><sup>+</sup> ion storage sites in hard carbons. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b displays the visual representation of Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage in expanded graphene layer and nanopore.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">5. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165"><span>In a nutshell, this article illustrates the feasibility of using ASR derived hard carbon as anode material in Na-ion battery. The consequences of <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonisation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonisation</a><span><span> temperature and the influences of the presence of various heteroatoms and defects on the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of anode materials are utterly discussed here. Among all the anodes, ASR-11A exhibits better electrochemical performances owing to its extended interlayer spacing, presence of heteroatoms, oxygen containing functional groups, numerous defects, edges, and nanopores. The proposition of converting ASR into hard carbon can establish a new paradigm in the field of </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a> regarding the quest for optimal carbon active material and their sources. Moreover, further tailoring of the carbon properties, such as tuning the surface area and regulating the growth of the short range ordered carbon zone with expanded interlayer spacing, may result in a better electrochemical performance of the battery. Low ICE and capacity loss are considered as two major drawbacks of using hard carbons in NIB. Further research can be conducted to reduce the trapping ratio of Na</span></span><sup>+</sup><span> ions and the formation of thin, stable SEI layer ensuring high ICE and low-capacity loss. The ASR creates burden on the environment unless they are treated accordingly. However, ASR could be a valuable source for synthesising <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carbonaceous-material" title="Learn more about carbonaceous materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonaceous materials</a> for using as carbon active material in rechargeable batteries. The utilisation of ASR in rechargeable batteries, such as Na-ion batteries, will help to overcome the harsh impact caused by landfilled ASR and, alongside, ensure material sustainability.</span></div></section><section id="sec6"><h2 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170"><strong>Montajar Sarkar:</strong> equally performed the experiments, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft. <strong>Rumana Hossain:</strong> equally performed the experiments, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft, Conceptualization, designed the experiment. <strong>Veena Sahajwalla:</strong> Supervision, Formal analysis, gave suggestions to revise the manuscript.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgment</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">This research was supported by the <span id="gs1">Australian Research Council’s Industrial Transformation Research</span> Hub funding scheme (project <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">IH190100009</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="appsec1"><h2 id="sectitle0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-34548825669&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref75"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Single%20sheet%20functionalized%20graphene%20by%20oxidation%20and%20thermal%20expansion%20of%20graphite&amp;publication_year=2007&amp;author=M.J.%20McAllister" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref75"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (10)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324010929"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A review on carbon materials for electrochemical energy storage applications: State of the art, implementation, and synergy with metallic compounds for supercapacitor and battery electrodes</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Power Sources</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Precursors of diverse natures are suitable for producing hard carbons for sodium-ion batteries. Sarkar et al. [339] selected automotive shredder residue as a precursor for this purpose. During the process, the precursor was thermally treated in a single step at temperatures of 700, 900, or 1100 °C for 1 h in an inert atmosphere.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Carbon materials play a fundamental role in electrochemical energy storage due to their appealing properties, including low cost, high availability, low environmental impact, surface functional groups, high electrical conductivity, alongside thermal, mechanical, and chemical stability, among other factors. Currently, carbon materials can be considered the most extensively explored family in the field of supercapacitors and batteries, which are devices covering a wide range of applications demanding high power and high energy. However, as with all technologies, there is a process of adaptation and optimization; hence, carbon materials have been aligning with the advances that emerge. Similarly, over the years, new methods and processes have been discovered to produce carbons more suitable for energy storage, adapting them to present a good synergy with metal-based compounds to meet current standards. In this work, we present a compilation of advances in the field of carbon materials used in supercapacitors and batteries, from the inception of these technologies to the present day.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324010681"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Recent progress on hard carbon-based anode for sodium-ion battery</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Power Sources</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The anode exhibits a specific capacity of 350 mAh g−1 and a plateau capacity of 250 at current density of 0.1 A g−1. Sarkar et al. prepared HC anode with high specific capacity (434 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1) by carbonizing automotive shredder residue at 1100 °C [83]. Li et al. obtained high performance HC anode by pyrolysis of renew able cotton at different temperature.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">In recent years, hard carbon (HC) has been considered as a potential anode material for sodium-ion batteries due to its ideal internal structure (pore structure, defect, etc.) and large carbon layer spacing. This paper summarizes the work in recent years and expounds the development trend of HC anode, hoping to help more scholars cope with the opportunities and challenges of HC materials in the future. In this paper, the mechanism and different model of Na<sup>+</sup> storage in HC are described in detail to guide the structural design of HC. In addition, the classification, electrochemical performance and synthesis mechanism of advanced HC materials are discussed comprehensively. Finally, the challenges and future development direction of HC are concluded, which can provide reference for the commercialization of sodium-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0016236124012894"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Biomass derived hard carbon materials for sodium ion battery anodes: Exploring the influence of carbon source on structure and sodium storage performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Fuel</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), emerging as a promising alternative among secondary ion batteries, are poised to supplant lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in large-scale energy storage applications. Their attributes, including commendable cost-effectiveness, safety profile, and portability, render them pivotal in mitigating the environmental repercussions stemming from the overreliance on fossil fuels [1–3]. However, current research on SIB mainly focuses on cathode materials, such as layered metal oxides [4,5], polyanionic compounds [6–8], and Prussian blue compounds [9].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Compared to the scarce resources of lithium-ion batteries, sodium ion batteries have gradually become an ideal carrier for large-scale energy storage systems due to their abundant raw material resources. In recent years, hard carbon as an anode material for sodium ion batteries has attracted much attention. Biomass materials have become an ideal hard carbon precursor due to their natural and renewable advantages. This article evaluates the effect of hard carbon derived from three types of biomass waste (peanut shell, coffee grounds, and sugarcane bagasse) on the electrochemical performance of sodium ion batteries through pre carbonization pyrolysis method. The three materials exhibit different structures and surface functional group contents. Compared with coffee grounds and sugarcane bagasse, peanut shell-derived hard carbon has lower structural ordering and smaller specific surface area, and exhibits a higher initial Coulombic efficiency of 53.84&nbsp;%. The initial reversible capacity of the HC-P electrode is 203.6 mAh/g, and the Coulombic efficiency of the electrode is close to 100&nbsp;% with a reversible capacity of 127.1 mAh/g and a capacity retention of 81.4&nbsp;% after cycling 100 at 1C current. The excellent electrochemical properties of HC-P can be attributed to its higher C=O bond content, larger layer spacing and lamellar structure.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0030402624001323"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Synthesis of highly efficient ternary phase graphene/Bi/SnO&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; photocatalyst for degradation of organic dye pollutants</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Optik</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Therefore, novel methods and materials shall be investigated to utilize these waste materials for multiple applications. Recently, carbon-based materials, such as graphite, carbon nanotubes and graphene, have attended significant interest in various energy, catalysis, and electronics applications [8–13]. The synthesis of these materials is a hot topic in scientific research and technology to reduce its cost for large scale applications.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0055">In this work, graphene nanosheets (GNs) are prepared from graphite rods obtained from waste dry-cell batteries using the electrochemical exfoliation (ECE) method. Then GNs used as a matrix to modify tin oxide (SnO<sub>2</sub>) and Bismuth (Bi) nanoparticles to prepare a binary phase SnO<sub>2</sub>@G and ternary-phase Bi@SnO<sub>2</sub>@G nanocomposite materials by wet-chemical method and used as a photocatalysts for degradation of organic dye pollutants. XRD diffraction pattern clearly confirmed the presence of tetragonal crystal system of SnO<sub>2</sub> which was maintaining its structure in SnO<sub>2</sub>@G and G/Bi/SnO<sub>2</sub>. The stretching and bending vibrations of the functional groups were analyzed using FTIR analysis. FESEM images demonstrated the surface morphology and the texture of the as synthesized sample. Raman Spectroscopic investigation was carried out to confirm the in-plane blending of SnO<sub>2</sub> and graphene inside the composite matrix. The as-prepared ternary-phase Bi@SnO<sub>2</sub>@G-based photocatalyst showed high degradation efficiency of 99.6% and 94.5% for direct blue (DB) and methyl blue (MB) dyes, respectively, under visible light irradiation by (i) minimizing the hole and electron recombination, (ii) providing a high surface area, and (iii) reducing the band gap energy. This study provides an effective, low-cost, and smart approach for producing GNs on a wide scale from battery waste along with nanohybrid composites with high photocatalytic efficiency.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.energyfuels.4c00980" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Recent Progress and Prospects on Sodium-Ion Battery and All-Solid-State Sodium Battery: A Promising Choice of Future Batteries for Energy Storage</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Energy and Fuels</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsaem.4c00592" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Empowering Energy Storage Technology: Recent Breakthroughs and Advancement in Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, ACS Applied Energy Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left" href="http://www.scopus.com/scopus/inward/citedby.url?partnerID=10&amp;rel=3.0.0&amp;eid=2-s2.0-85170410167&amp;md5=ce25447ad6e7f3ebd130cff7669972b" target="_blank" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span batteries</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Materials Today Communications, Volume 37, 2023, Article 107361</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Xiaochuan</span> <span>Chen</span>, …, <span>Xiaoyan</span> <span>Li</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S2352492823020524/pdfft?md5=c84d4899986578855c6992e47157db2f&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S2352492823020524-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article1-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" 0h2.63v.934h-1.657v.894H16.6V6.4h-1.56v2.026h-.97V3.638"></path><path d="M19.462 13.46c.348 4.274-6.59 16.72-8.508 15.792-1.82-.85 1.53-3.317 2.92-4.366-2.864.894-5.394 3.252-3.837 3.93 2.113.895 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-block"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article2-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2452262723000405" title="Nickel-templated carbon foam anodes for sodium-ion batteries"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Nickel-templated carbon foam anodes for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">FlatChem, Volume 40, 2023, Article 100508</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Jinjue</span> <span>Zeng</span>, …, <span>Xiangfen</span> <span>Jiang</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon"       y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>

          'HTML-CSS': { linebreaks: { automatic: true } },
          SVG: {
            scale: 90,
            linebreaks: { automatic: true }
          }
        });
      </script>
