work)</strong></td><td class="align-left" rowspan="3"><strong>1100</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>10</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>1</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>434</strong></td><td class="align-left" rowspan="3"><strong>No additional material treatment.</strong></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left"><strong>10</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>25</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>282</strong></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left"><strong>100</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>100</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>70</strong></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">The automotive shredder residue (ASR) used in this experimental study was supplied by OneSteel Australia. The as received ASRs were profuse in wood and plastic. The composition of the as received ASR is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">At the very onset of this study, the ground ASR was thermally transformed into hard carbon via a single step process. For thermal transformation, ASR was heat treated at 700 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-74-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-74"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, 900 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-75-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-75"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, and 1100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-76-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-76"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span> for 1&nbsp;h in a High Temperature Tube Furnace in an inert atmosphere created by nitrogen <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/gas-flow" title="Learn more about gas flow from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">gas flow</a> at the rate of 1L/min. The experimental conditions and furnace schematic are demonstrated in supporting information (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>). The hard carbon synthesised at 700 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-77-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-77"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, 900 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-78-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-78"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, and 1100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-79-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-79"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> are identified as ASR-7, ASR-9, and ASR-11 respectively. These hard carbons were used and assessed as anode active material in Na-ion battery. The anodes made from ASR-7, ASR-9, ASR-11 are named ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A respectively.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Materials characterisation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span><span>To study the compositions, morphology and microstructure of the hard carbons, the ASR-7, ASR-9, and ASR-11 were characterised in depth by <a href="/topics/materials-science/elemental-analysis" title="Learn more about CHNS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CHNS analysis</a>, X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF), X-ray </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/photoelectron" title="Learn more about photoelectron from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photoelectron</a> spectroscopy (XPS), thermal gravimetric/thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, X-ray diffraction (XRD), </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a><span> (TEM) and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/laser-ablation" title="Learn more about laser ablation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">laser ablation</a> </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/inductively-coupled-plasma-mass-spectrometry" title="Learn more about inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry</a><span> (LA-ICP-MS) analytical technique was used to measure the elemental composition of ASR. The percentage of remaining carbon in ASR composition was estimated by LECO CS230 carbon and sulfur analyser. Furthermore, the carbon, hydrogen, sulfur, and oxygen percentage in ASR were estimated by utilising CHNSO combustion analyser. An Elementar vario MACRO CUBE and a rapid OXY CUBE were used for CHNS and O analysis respectively. To understand the <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermal-degradation" title="Learn more about thermal degradation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal degradation</a> behavior of ASR, TGA was performed by using a PerkinElmer TGA 800 thermal gravimetric analyser. BET test was accomplished on a Micromeritics TriStar 3020 II surface analysis system. For X-ray diffraction analysis, the samples were scanned from 10 </span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-80-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.162ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 500.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 1.257ex; margin-bottom: -1.377ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-80"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></script></span> to 50 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-81-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.162ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 500.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 1.257ex; margin-bottom: -1.377ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-81"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></script></span> in a PANalytical X'Pert Multipurpose XRD System (MPD) equipped with Cu K <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-82-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B1;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.488ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 640.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B1"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-82"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></script></span> radiation (λ&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.541&nbsp;Å). The TEM images were captured in JEOL TEM-F200, operated in TEM mode at spot size 1, angle 5, emission current 14 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-83-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BC;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.402ex" height="1.855ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 603.5 798.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BC"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">μ</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-83"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">μ</mi></mrow></math></script></span> m, and 200&nbsp;kV accelerating voltage. An ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Scientific, UK) X-ray photoelectron spectrometer was utilised for measuring the chemical states of elements present at the surface of the materials. The XPS analyser was equipped with a mono-chromated Al K<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-84-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B1;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.488ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 640.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B1"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-84"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">α</mi></mrow></math></script></span><span> (hʋ&nbsp;=&nbsp;1486.68&nbsp;eV) X-ray source. The XPS analysis was performed in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultrahigh-vacuum" title="Learn more about ultrahigh vacuum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ultrahigh vacuum</a> (∼2&nbsp;×&nbsp;10</span><sup>−9</sup>&nbsp;mbar) with a photoelectron take off angle of 90 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-85-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.162ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 500.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 1.257ex; margin-bottom: -1.377ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-85"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span>. C1s (at 284.5&nbsp;eV) of graphite was used as the binding energy reference. For Raman characterisation, a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope was used equipped with an <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/argon-laser" title="Learn more about argon ion laser from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">argon ion laser</a> of 532&nbsp;nm.</span></div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. The electrochemical measurements of half-cell</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>At the very outset of electrochemical measurement, the hard carbon-based electrodes were fabricated to study the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performances from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performances</a><span> of hard carbons as electrode materials of NIB. For preparing the electrodes, the hard carbons, carbon black (AVT services), and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a> fluoride (PVDF; AVT services) binder were mixed at the weight ratio of 85:10:5 to make a powder mixture. Then the N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP; sigma Aldrich) was added dropwise to the mixture followed by magnetic stirring of the mixture for 24&nbsp;h to form a viscous slurry. The slurry was coated (coating thickness was 80 </span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-86-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BC;</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>m</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.442ex" height="1.855ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 1482 798.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BC"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(603,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6D"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">μ</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-86"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">μ</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></mrow></math></script></span>) in a copper foil by a notch bar and dried in a vacuum oven at 100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-87-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-87"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> for 12&nbsp;h. After the vacuum drying, to improve the adhesion between the pasted electrode and copper foil, the electrode sheets were pressed at 100&nbsp;kN pressure for 1&nbsp;h by using a flat-plate presser (MTI corporation). These sheets were then dried in a vacuum oven at 100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-88-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-88"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span> for 6&nbsp;h then transferred in glovebox filled with argon. Inside the glovebox the electrode sheets were pressed to form 12&nbsp;mm discs with the help of a handheld punching machine. CR2032 type NIB half cells were prepared by using hard carbon-based electrodes as anode, pure <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> metal as counter electrode, and 16&nbsp;mm glass fibre (Whatman, grade GF/F) as separator. 1&nbsp;M NaPF</span><sub>6</sub> in ethylene carbonate (EC)/dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (1:1 by volume) was employed as electrolyte. 41,42 NaPF<sub>6</sub>, DMC, and EC were delivered from Sigma-Aldrich. A Neware BTS3000 battery cycler was employed for cycling the cells galvanostatically between 0.01v-2.5v at varying current densities. The applied current values were measured depending on the mass loading (4.5&nbsp;mg/cm<sup>2</sup>) of electroactive materials at the electrodes (foil with 12&nbsp;mm diameter contained 5.0&nbsp;mg active material).</div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Result and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">The percentage of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, sulfur, and oxygen in ASR and thermally treated ASR residue (hard carbons) was measured by CHNSO analyser. The LECO CS230 analyser was used for measuring the amount of residual carbon in the samples. The elemental composition of ASR samples measured by LA-ICP-MS and LECO CS230 analyser is summarised in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl2" name="btbl2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl2"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="tspara0015"><span class="label">Table 2</span>. Trace elements and carbon content in ASR samples.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">Sample</th><th scope="col">C (%)</th><th scope="col">Si (%)</th><th scope="col">Ti (%)</th><th scope="col">Ca (%)</th><th scope="col">Mg (%)</th><th scope="col">Al (%)</th><th scope="col">Sb (%)</th><th scope="col">Br (%)</th><th scope="col">Cl (%)</th><th scope="col">Cu (%)</th><th scope="col">Fe (%)</th><th scope="col">K (%)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR</td><td class="align-left">19.43</td><td class="align-left">0.79</td><td class="align-left">0.37</td><td class="align-left">1.09</td><td class="align-left">0.18</td><td class="align-left">0.09</td><td class="align-left">2.32</td><td class="align-left">2.43</td><td class="align-left">0.23</td><td class="align-left">0.003</td><td class="align-left">0.01</td><td class="align-left">0.23</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-7</td><td class="align-left">80.12</td><td class="align-left">0.95</td><td class="align-left">0.73</td><td class="align-left">1.91</td><td class="align-left">0.28</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0.02</td><td class="align-left">0.04</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.08</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0.15</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-9</td><td class="align-left">81.11</td><td class="align-left">0.94</td><td class="align-left">0.71</td><td class="align-left">1.9</td><td class="align-left">0.28</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.04</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.08</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-11</td><td class="align-left">81.12</td><td class="align-left">0.97</td><td class="align-left">0.71</td><td class="align-left">1.9</td><td class="align-left">0.28</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.04</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.08</td><td class="align-left">0.2</td><td class="align-left">0</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">Carbon percentage in ASR samples measured by both LECO CS230 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl2" name="btbl2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>) and CHNSO analyser (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>) are quite similar. Nitrogen content (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a><span>) increased significantly with increasing the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonisation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonisation</a><span> temperature. This phenomenon can be associated with thermal transformation of nitrogen into stable phases at higher temperature. The elemental data analysis summarises that the hard carbons consist of 80–81% carbon and 10–20% different kinds of heteroatoms. This huge number of heteroatoms influences the performances of hard carbons during electrochemical operation. The impact of the presence of heteroatoms on potentiogram of hard carbons has been illustrated in subsequent sections. To understand the thermal stability of ASR, the ASR was subjected to <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about thermal gravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal gravimetric analysis</a>. The ASR begun to degrade around 350 </span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-89-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-89"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3a</span></span></a>) and continued till the temperature reached around 525 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-90-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-90"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span>. Throughout this <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermal-degradation" title="Learn more about thermal degradation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal degradation</a> process, ASR loses around 30% of its mass. The Thermal degradation of ASR shows a step around 450 </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-91-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-91"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a>). Beyond <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-92-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-92"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 525<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-93-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-94"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 525<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-95-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-95"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl3"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="tspara0020"><span class="label">Table 3</span>. Percentage of N, O, C, H, and S in ASR samples measured by CHNSO combustion analyser.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">Sample</th><th scope="col">N (%)</th><th scope="col">O (%)</th><th scope="col">C (%)</th><th scope="col">H (%)</th><th scope="col">S (%)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR</td><td class="align-left">0.21</td><td class="align-left">6.32</td><td class="align-left">20.32</td><td class="align-left">1.05</td><td class="align-left">0.35</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-7</td><td class="align-left">1.61</td><td class="align-left">7.31</td><td class="align-left">80.23</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0.01</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-9</td><td class="align-left">1.74</td><td class="align-left">8.11</td><td class="align-left">81.31</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">ASR-11</td><td class="align-left">1.73</td><td class="align-left">8.36</td><td class="align-left">81.29</td><td class="align-left">0</td><td class="align-left">0</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><span>The elemental composition of the hard carbons, and anodes (after charging and discharging) was estimated by <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS analysis</a>. The elements identified at the surface of the hard carbons are mainly C, O, and Na. Pristine ASR sample is the source for most of these elements. The presence of Na in the XPS spectra is not surprising. The presence of Na can be related to Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> ion intercalation in hard carbons during electrochemical operation. One of the prime objectives behind the XPS study was to reveal the changes that took place regarding the composition, bond association and chemical states of elements at the surface of <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> due to charging and discharging. The deconvoluted C1s peaks at 284.8&nbsp;eV, </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-96-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-101"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 291.0&nbsp;eV can be associated with C–C(sp<sup>2</sup>/sp<sup>3</sup>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" The C1s peak at 283.75&nbsp;eV indicates the presence of Si–C bond [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>]. Similarly, the deconvoluted O1s peak at <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-103-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math associated with <a href="/topics/materials-science/quinone" title="Learn more about quinone from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">quinone</a> (C</span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a><span>], <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/phenol" title="Learn more about phenol from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phenol</a> (C–OH)/ether (C–O–C) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference"
