respectively.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> displays the deconvoluted C1s, O1s XPS spectra of hard carbons. The deconvoluted C1s and Na peak of anodes (ASR 7A, ASR 9A, and ASR 11A) are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S4, S5, and S6</span></span></a>. The Na-Auger peak in XPS spectra can be associated with Na intercalation during operation. The peak of Na spectrum at <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-106-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-106"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 1071&nbsp;eV can be associated with Na/NaF/Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>. The presence of NaF/Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub><span> indicates the formation of <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about SEI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEI</a> layer at the surface of hard carbons during electrochemical operation. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a> displays the survey spectra of all the hard carbons.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr1.jpg" height="322" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (657KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (657KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (i) Deconvoluted C1s (a), O1s (b) XPS spectra of ASR-7 hard carbons; (ii) Deconvoluted C1s (c), O1s (d) XPS spectra of ASR-9 hard carbons; and (iii) Deconvoluted C1s (e), O1s (f) XPS spectra of ASR-11 hard carbons.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">The X-ray diffractogram in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>a depicts the <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD pattern from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD pattern</a> of ASR-7, ASR-9, and ASR-11. The diffractogram indicates the presence of three different titanium oxides (TiO</span><sub>2</sub>, TiO, and Ti<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) in the hard carbons. Among all these titanium oxides, TiO<sub>2</sub> is the dominating phase. No sharp peak of carbon is observed in diffractogram. Instead of sharp peak, one broad peak is visible at <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-107-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-107"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 23<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-108-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-108"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>. The broader shape of the peak at <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-109-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-109"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 23<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-110-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-110"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span> indicates that the hard carbon is <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> in nature with large interlayer spacing. The large interlayer spacing is convenient for Na</span><sup>+</sup> ion storage and moving between graphite layers [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>] during electrochemical operation. The N<sub>2</sub><span> absorption isotherm and <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> of all hard carbons is displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f. ASR-7 has the highest specific surface area (97.18&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup>/g). With temperature the specific surface area decreases drastically and becomes 9.80&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup>/g at 1100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-111-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-111"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span>. The specific surface area decreases mainly due to elimination of micropores from the hard carbons. Along with pore elimination, the internal ordering of the carbon atoms at higher temperature is also responsible for the decrease in specific surface area. The evolution of micropores and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a> can be defined in the following ways. The presence of micropores at 700 </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-112-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-112"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> might be due to the poor structural ordering of carbon (C–C) aromatic structures.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr2.jpg" height="299" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (572KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (572KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(i) The X-ray diffractogram of ASR-7, ASR-9, and ASR-11 (a); (ii) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span> of hard carbons (b); (iii) The Na <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nmr-spectra" title="Learn more about NMR spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NMR spectra</a> of hard carbons after electrochemical operation: (c) ASR 7, (d) ASR 9, and (e) ASR 11; (iv) N</span></span><sub>2</sub><span> absorption and isothermal liner plot of hard carbons (f), and <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> of hard carbons (g).</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">With increasing temperature, graphene layers grow, and some carbon atoms leave the lattice via CO<sub>x</sub> formation. These high temperature chemicals and structural consequences were responsible for mesopore formation. Besides, the rotation of ordered carbon layers might also be responsible for mesopore evolution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. The elimination of micropores and evolution of mesopores help in achieving high initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of anode during electrochemical operation. The reason is, elimination of micropores decreases the surface area leading to lower volume of electrochemically active areas, thus helped in formation of thin, stable, and uniform SEI layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f demonstrates that with temperature the surface area of hard carbons decreased which helped in attaining high ICE of ASR-11A (ICE&nbsp;=&nbsp;52.9%) compared with ASR-7A (ICE&nbsp;=&nbsp;20.9%). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(c, d, and e) depicts the Na NMR results of the hard carbons after charging and discharging. The Na NMR results have been illustrated here to reveal the electrochemical interaction of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> in hard carbons. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nmr-spectra" title="Learn more about NMR spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NMR spectra</a> reveal that the magnitude of the charge spectra is lower than that of the discharge spectra. This observation corroborates with measured capacity (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>a, b, and c) of the anodes where it is demonstrated that the charge capacity is lower than the discharge capacity. The diminished charge spectra and subsequent capacity loss can be assigned with the SEI layer formation at the hard <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about carbon surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon surface</a> and trapping of Na in hard carbons [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. The NMR spectra exhibits 4–6 Na active sites which can be described as: (i) The peak at -2&nbsp;ppm can be assigned to Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>. The use of carbonate in electrolyte preparation or the presence of carbonate in SEI layer could be responsible for the evolution of this peak; (ii) The broad NMR peak at −10&nbsp;ppm can be attributed to NaPF<sub>6</sub><span> or the fluoride salt present in the SEI layer; (iii) −12&nbsp;ppm peak position can be assigned with the Na adsorption at the carbon surface; (iv) The NMR peak at −14&nbsp;ppm can be attributed to <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopore from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopore</a> filling of hard carbons with Na</span><sup>+</sup> ions; (v) Anodes made from ASR-9 and ASR-11 show a shoulder peak at 10&nbsp;ppm. This indicates that ASR-9 and ASR-11 have more active sites for Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage than ASR-7. Careful observation of NMR spectra reveals that the discharge spectra only have the 10&nbsp;ppm signal which means the active site at 10&nbsp;ppm is completely cyclable. Therefore, it can be stated that Na can be completely extracted during charging from this active site. This phenomenon of reversibility of Na<sup>+</sup> ion insertion and extraction can be assigned with Na<sup>+</sup> ion intercalation at extended graphitic layers of hard carbons; (vi) The anode made from ASR-11 shows an additional peak at −18&nbsp;ppm. This Na active site can be attributed to nanopore filling by Na<sup>+</sup><span> ion. This indicates that ASR-11 has a different <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-structure" title="Learn more about pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore structure</a> than the other hard carbons. BET results can be corroborated with the above explanation as it is indicated from BET results (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g) that ASR-11 has maximum volume of mesopore. The NMR results indicate that ASR-11 has more Na active sites than the other hard carbons which helps ASR-11 to store more Na<sup>+</sup> ions, culminating in higher capacity than the ASR-9 and ASR-7.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr3.jpg" height="465" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (688KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (688KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Potential profile of electrodes: (a) ASR 11A, (b) ASR 9A, and (c) ASR 7A; (d) Sloping and plateau capacity of each electrode.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105"><span>The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b shows the Raman features of hard carbons. The Raman peaks at <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-113-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-113"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 1340&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-114-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-114"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 1590&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> of every sample can be associated with D-band and G-band respectively. The D-band shows up in the Raman spectra due to the presence of defects and/or pore in sp<sup>2</sup> carbons. The G-band is the consequence of graphitic carbon. The concentration of defects and the purity of the crystals of hard carbons can be approximated via Raman band intensity ratio. The band ratio of every spectrum has been stated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b. The band ratio of the hard carbons gradually increases with increasing the temperature. The increasing trend of Raman band ratio (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub>) indicates the presence of defects along the graphene plane [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]. The band ratio reveals that ASR-11 has maximum concentration of defects. However, there is no distinct definition which can be assigned to the defect sites present in the hard carbons. Usually, the defect sites are reactive dangling bond at the surface, vacancies/holes at the interior of carbon plane, Stone-Wales defects, curved graphene sheet, sp<sup>3</sup> linked carbon, heteroatoms (metal and nonmetal) bonded to the carbons [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a><span>]. These defect-sites play an important role in sodiation potential particularly potential at the sloping region of potentiogram. The heterogenous environment (i.e., presence of heteroatoms, defects) of hard carbons enhances the electrochemical performances. The heteroatoms act as in situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/doping-additives" title="Learn more about dopants from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dopants</a> and create defect sites in host materials resulting in better adsorbility of sodium ions in defect sites [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>]. The powerful bonding energy of interaction between Na<sup>+</sup> ions and defects overcomes the van der Walls force between graphene layers which tremendously helps in Na<sup>+</sup> ion intercalation in defect sites [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">At this stage of discussion one legitimate question arises about the electrochemical performance of these hard carbons as anode materials in NIB. In the quest of finding the answer of the above interrogation, the hard carbons were punched into coin cells to use as electrode for evaluating the sodium storage performance as anode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a, b, and c display the potential profile (voltage Vs capacity profile) of all the hard carbons. The carbonisation temperature deeply influenced the shape of the profile. The profile is divided into two parts: (i) the sloping voltage profile (above 0.1V) related to heteroatom, defect sites, edges, and vacancies of the hard carbons, and (ii) the plateau voltage profile (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-115-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-115"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 0.1V) related to the ordered carbon and nanopore filling. All the hard carbons show different sloping voltage and plateau voltage capacity profile, which symbolises that the carbonisation temperature and the presence of active sites have their own individual effect on the shape of the potentiogram. Na<sup>+</sup> ion binding energy with carbon is highest at defect and vacancy sites, which can be corelated to the potential at the sloping region [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. Energetically it is in favor of Na<sup>+</sup> ion to anchor at the defect sites as the defect sites contain low energy empty shells which can easily store extra electrons [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>]. Besides the Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion in defect sites are much faster than the graphene sheets [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. Thus, it is accepted that sodiation at the initial stage of electrochemical operation is happened at the defect sites leading to rise of sloping potential before plateau potential. The sodiation at the plateau region occurs at low potential value. At such low voltage the sodium ion storage sites are characterised by low binding energy [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. Which indicates that the low voltage sodium ion storage occurs at the nanopores and between graphene layers because the graphene surface is considered energetically least favorable for Na<sup>+</sup> ion intercalation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. In consequence it is rational to state that low potential Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage occurs between graphene layers and at nanopore. The plateau capacity at <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-116-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-116"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 0.1V is associated with the short range ordered carbon zone and nanopore filling of hard carbons. Higher carbonisation temperature increases the plateau capacity of the hard carbons which can be attributed to the presence of ordered carbons around the defects in hard carbons. The presence of homogenous contact plate inside the ordered carbon zone are beneficial for Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage, creating the plateau capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d displays the initial capacity (sloping and plateau capacity) of all the anodes. With carbonisation temperature both the sloping capacity and plateau capacity are increased, which corroborates with the structural properties of hard carbons where it has been tried to demonstrate that with carbonisation temperature the amount of Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage sites are increased. Nonetheless, it is clear from <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d that ASR-11 has the highest number of active sites for Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage. However, it should be noted that increasing the carbonisation temperature may not always bring benefits for Na-ion battery. Higher carbonisation temperature causes horizontal growth (width (L<sub>a</sub>)) of the graphene layers and increases the average number of graphene layers. If the graphene layers become overly large, Na<sup>+</sup> ions need to diffuse through a longer diffusion path. Larger number of graphene layers and longer diffusion path limits the Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion rate during electrochemical operation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a><span>]. Besides, at higher temperature, the order of carbon atom rearrangement within the internal hard <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-structure" title="Learn more about carbon structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon structure</a> is increased owing to the higher thermal energy. Consequently, the carbon atoms arrange themselves in a more orderly manner, causing a decrease in d-spacing [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>]. The decrease in intergraphene layer spacing hinders the Na<sup>+</sup> ion transportation through the electrode material [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>]. Appropriate L<sub>a</sub> value of graphene layers not only boosts the electrochemical performance of anode materials, but also minimises the irreversible capacity loss of the battery. Considering the electrochemical performances and changes in structural properties of hard carbon with temperature, the maximum operational temperature during hard carbon synthesis in this study was kept at 1100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-117-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-117"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115"><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> images in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a> reveal the structural and morphological evolution of ASR derived hard carbons. The morphological transformation of the hard carbon went through different carbonisation temperatures (700 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="display: none;"></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-118-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-118"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span> −1100 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-119-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;C</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.841ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1223 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-119"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">°C</mo></mrow></math></script></span>) is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>a–c. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> images show that the carbon materials are neither ordered nor disordered, rather consist of several short range ordered carbon zone in the matrix of non-graphitic carbon, as anticipated for usual hard carbons. The ordered carbon zones consist of multi-layer short range stacked graphene, ranging from 2 to 10 layers. ASR-7 (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>a) is <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbon</a>, it composed of more disordered carbon than graphitised carbon. With increasing the carbonisation temperature, amount of graphitised carbon (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>b and c) increased which results in the formation of short range ordered carbon zone. Thus, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a> indicates that the hard carbon synthesised from ASR is a mixture of ordered and disordered carbon. With increasing the carbonisation temperature, the number of ordered carbon zone increased. These short range ordered carbon zone helped in attaining better electrochemical performance. In </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a, the ASR-7 hard carbon exhibits a substantial lack of orderliness. The amount of short range ordered carbon is very low in ASR-7. Instead of having significant amount of short range ordered carbon, ASR-7 got bigger volume of disordered carbon (non-graphitic carbon). ASR-9 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b) has some short range ordered carbon zone, but the amount is lesser than the ASR-11. Lack of significant amount ordered carbon in ASR-7 and ASR-9 is most likely owing to the absence of enough energy for driving the growth of ordered carbon structure. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c depicts that ASR-11 has more rumpled nanodomain of ordered carbon with expanded d-spacing than ASR-7 and ASR-9. Expanded interlayer spacing of hard carbons is favorable for Na<sup>+</sup> ion intercalation and deintercalation during electrochemical operation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. The better electrochemical performances of ASR-11A corroborate with improved structural and morphological features of ASR-11. Electrochemical information provided in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d shows that ASR-11A has the highest plateau capacity among all the anodes. Which means, the rumpled nanodomain with large interlayer spacing enabled ASR-11A to attain high plateau capacity. From the literature till now it is demonstrated that the large d-spacing of hard carbon is thermodynamically preferable for Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage. And the presence of rumpled and short-range ordered carbon zones (TEM images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>) contribute to the plateau capacity of potentiogram. Besides, the randomly distributed amorphous regions (disordered/non-graphitic carbon) contain huge amount of nanovoids which help in Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage during the electrochemical operation of the anode.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr4.jpg" height="509" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (i)HR-TEM images of Hard Carbons: (a) ASR 7, (b) ASR 9, and (c) ASR 11; (ii) Electrochemical data of electrodes made from hard carbons derived from ASR: (d) Cyclic performance of all the anodes, (e) Rate performance graph of ASR 11A, (f) Nyquist plot (EIS spectrum) of the anodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The potential profile of the anodes is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a, b, and c. The very first discharge capacity of ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A are 311.9mAh/g, 359.1mAh/g, and 434.2mAh/g respectively. The large capacity value of ASR-11A indicates the presence of more active sites for Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage in ASR-11A than ASR-7A, and ASR-9A. These active sites are defects, edges, pore, and ordered carbon layers [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a>]. In the case of first discharge capacity, the capacity at <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-120-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-120"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 0.1V increases with temperature. The plateau capacity of ASR-11A and ASR-9A can be related with Na<sup>+</sup> ion insertion into expanded interlayer spacing and nanopore [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib60" name="bbib60" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib60"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">60</span></span></a>]. The plateau capacity of ASR-7A is very low in comparison with ASR-11A and ASR-9A. The reason for low plateau capacity of ASR-7A could be the presence of lower volume of mesopore and absence of extended interlayer spacing. The first charge capacity of ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A are 65.4mAh/g, 147.3mAh/g, and 230.1mAh/g respectively. The corresponding coulombic efficiency (CE) of first cycle of the anodes are 20.9%, 41.1%, and 52.9% for ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A respectively. Though the ICE is increased with temperature, still the value is low. This indicates the high trapping ratio of Na<sup>+</sup> ions in hard carbons during first cycle. In this consequence, the micropores at the surface of hard carbons or between the graphene sheets can be accused for trapping Na<sup>+</sup> ions and result in low CE and capacity loss [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib61" name="bbib61" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib61"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. Correlation of the ICE value with BET result, reveals that ASR-7 has the highest volume of micropores and low ICE (20.9%). On the contrary, ASR-11 has the lowest volume of micropores and high ICE (52.9%).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">From the potential profiles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a, b, and c) of all the anodes, it is clearly seen that a large irreversibility exists between the first charge and discharge cycle. The calculated irreversible capacity loss of anodes after first cycle is 79.2%, 50.1%, and 46.9% for ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A respectively. The irreversible capacity loss of the anodes after first cycle is related to the SEI (solid electrolyte interface) layer formation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>]. Along with the SEI layer, the high irreversible capacity loss of ASR-7A (79.2%) can be assigned to the structural disorderliness of carbon in ASR-7 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. The cycling performances of the anodes at 10&nbsp;mA/g up to 100 cycles were measured and displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d. It is acknowledged that ASR-11A provides highest capacity (434.2mAh/g) and capacity retention (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-121-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-121"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 53%) owing to suitable Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage sites. The CE of ASR-11A is displayed along with the cyclic performance data in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d. Though the ICE (52.9%) of ASR-11A is low, but with cycle number the CE increases and goes beyond 95%. ASR-11A exhibits better electrochemical performance than the ASR-7A and ASR-9A, thus the rate performance of only ASR-11A at different current density (10&nbsp;mA/g to 100&nbsp;mA/g to 10&nbsp;mA/g) is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e. With increasing the current density, the capacity of ASR-11A decreases and becomes <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-122-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-122"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 70mAh/g at 100&nbsp;mA/g. When the current density is reset to 10&nbsp;mA/g, the capacity increases again and reaches to <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-123-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x223C;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.163ex" viewBox="0 -449.1 778.5 500.8" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.307ex; margin-bottom: -0.427ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-223C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-123"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">∼</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 210mAh/g. This capacity recovery phenomenon indicates that ASR-11A possess good rate capability and material tolerance to fast Na<sup>+</sup> ion insertion/extraction. The electrochemical kinetics of the anodes after 10 cycles are depicted via electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f. All the EIS spectra show one semicircle succeeded by a liner slope at lower frequency region. The semicircle of the EIS spectrum is usually considered to be responsible for the combined resistance offered by SEI layer (R<sub>SEI</sub>; lower frequency range) and charge transfer (R<sub>ct</sub>; higher frequency range). The liner slope is usually associated to Warburg impedance related with solid state Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion. In addition, the first intercept of the EIS spectrum with X-axis is considered as ion diffusion resistance (R<sub>e</sub>) in electrolyte [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib64" name="bbib64" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib64"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">64</span></span></a>]. The calculated R<sub>e</sub> value of the ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A are approximately 18 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-124-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.678ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 722.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-124"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></script></span>, 5 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-125-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.678ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 722.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-125"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></script></span> and 4 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-126-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.678ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 722.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-126"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></script></span> respectively. Besides, the R<sub>SEI</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;R<sub>ct</sub> values of ASR-7A, ASR-9A, and ASR-11A are approximately 410 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-127-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.678ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 722.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-127"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></script></span>, 352 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-128-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.678ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 722.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-128"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></script></span> and 260 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-129-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.678ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 722.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-129"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ω</mi></mrow></math></script></span> respectively. The SEI results depict that ASR-11A exhibit lowest resistance value compared to other electrodes. This lower resistance of ASR-11A can be assigned to the suitable short range ordered carbon zone with expanded interlayer spacing where Na<sup>+</sup> ion can get easily stored during cyclic operation. The low electrochemical resistance value of ASR-11A corroborates with its highest discharge capacity, better rate and cyclic performances compared to other anodes. Moreover, the presence of heteroatoms also influences the EIS spectrum. The presence of heteroatoms increases the conductivity of the carbons (effects of the presence of heteroatoms are discussed in section <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec4" name="bsec4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>) which results in lower electrochemical resistance, better electrochemical performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib65" name="bbib65" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib65"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[65]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[66]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib67" name="bbib67" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib67"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[67]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">In conclusion of electrochemical performance of ASR derived hard carbon it can be stated that ASR-7A showed poor electrochemical performance owing to the lack of active sodium ion storage sites. On the contrary ASR-11A showed admirable electrochemical performance due to the presence of active sodium ion storage sites like defects, short range ordered carbon zone with large inter layer spacing, and nanopore.</div></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;storage mechanism in hard carbon during electrochemical operation</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0135">The hard carbons used in this research work store the Na<sup>+</sup> ions during electrochemical operation usually via three mechanisms: insertion/intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> ions, alloying of Na<sup>+</sup> ions or conversion of Na<sup>+</sup> ions. These mechanisms have been discussed here briefly. Insertion or intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> ions in hard carbon is defined as storage of Na<sup>+</sup> ions inside the hard carbon without affecting the crystalline parameters of the hard carbon (the schematic of Na insertion has been displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a). When Na<sup>+</sup><span> ions are inserted into the hard carbon, it forces some of the electrons to leave the structure. This indicates that the hard carbons must possess some atoms (heteroatoms) which are easily oxidised and reduced, and the hard carbons must possess moderate <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a>. One important aspect of Na</span><sup>+</sup> ions intercalation must be mentioned, for Na<sup>+</sup> ions insertion, the hard carbons must possess expanded interlayer spacing. Because, the diameter of Na<sup>+</sup> ions (0.204&nbsp;nm) is pretty big for accommodating in interlayer spacing of graphite (0.335&nbsp;nm), thus Na<sup>+</sup> ions hardly creates stagged compounds with perfectly ordered carbon (i.e. graphite) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib68" name="bbib68" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib68"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">68</span></span></a>]. The TEM images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a–c) display that the hard carbons have large interlayer spacing where they can easily store Na<sup>+</sup> ions. Expanded interlayer spacing facilitates Na<sup>+</sup> ions intercalation and deintercalation during electrochemical operation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>]. The Na<sup>+</sup> ions insertion into hard carbons can be expressed via the following equation.<span class="display"><span id="fd1" class="formula"><span class="label">1</span><span xlink:href="#MJMAIN-43"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mrow id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775323009539-gr5.jpg" height="290" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. Visual representation of Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;ions storage in hard carbons: (a) Na<sup>+</sup> ions storage at different defect sites; (b) Na<sup>+</sup> ions storage in nano pore and between two expanded graphene layers; (c) Deformation of graphene layer due to the presence of different size heteroatoms; (d) Enlarging in interlayer spacing due to the presence of heteroatoms and functional groups.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">The elemental characterisation (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl2" name="btbl2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>) reveals that the hard carbon contains a significant number of heteroatoms (i.e., Si, N, Al, Ca, Mg, Fe, etc.). Heteroatoms like Si and N, from group number 14 and 15 can react with the Na<sup>+</sup><span> ions and form <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/intermetallics" title="Learn more about intermetallic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">intermetallic</a> compounds which are considered as alloying or dealloying of these elements with Na. These alloying or dealloying of heteroatoms with Na</span><sup>+</sup> ions increase the specific capacity because one single atom can anchor multiple Na atoms. The alloying or dealloying reaction of these elements with Na<sup>+</sup> ions has been stated below.<span class="display"><span id="fd2" class="formula"><span class="label">2</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-131-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>,</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>,</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>y</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>z</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2212;</mo></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2192;</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>y</mi></msub><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="47.387ex" height="2.894ex" viewBox="0 -896.2 20402.6 1246" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1084,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true">M</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-131"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">t</mi><mi stretchy="true" is="true">→</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">y</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The equation of multi electron reaction during electrochemical operation can be expressed as below.<span class="display"><span id="fd3" class="formula"><span class="label">3</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7A"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1390,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5725,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7849,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8850,0)"><g is="true"><use
